Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story: I woke up to the sight of laundry overflowing from the basket, shirts and socks threatening to spill onto the hallway floor. My partner had left a note on the fridge: “Can you please fold the laundry today? I’m swamped at work.” I promised myself I’d get to it after my shift. As I slid behind the wheel of my taxi, the weight of that promise pressed on me. The day was busy, and my last fare needed to get across town fast. I took a shortcut, only to find myself in a school zone, the road squeezed by orange cones and construction barriers. Children clustered near the curb, their laughter and sudden movements making me grip the wheel tighter. I knew I had to drive slowly, carefully—no matter how late my passenger was running. But in the back of my mind, I pictured the laundry still waiting at home, my partner’s tired face, the unspoken expectation that I’d help out. The demands of both worlds pulled at me, and I felt caught between the rules of the road and the rules of my own home, unsure which responsibility should come first.
